awd_titl_txt: Kuiper Belt Dynamics with a Distant Unseen Planet
awd_abstract_narration:
In our solar system, Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs) are among the most distant objects from the sun.  Recently, astronomers have proposed the existence of a distant, unseen planet, popularly known as Planet 9.  Two pieces of evidence support this proposal.  First, the orbital characteristics of about a half-dozen of the most distant KBOs are very similar.  Second, the orbits of these KBOs are spaced in location so that they appear to be influenced by the presence of a much larger body.  This research will combine both theoretical, orbital dynamics studies of these highly-irregular orbital characteristics with orbit fitting and uncertainty estimation of the telescopic data on these KBOs.  The results will lead to a much better assessment of the evidence for Planet 9, and narrow the present location of Planet 9 in the sky.  This support the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of the solar system structure.  The investigators will add the results of their research to university courses and public lectures.

This research will elucidate the dynamics of orbital resonances over the full range of orbital eccentricities with the anticipation of discovery and understanding of novel phase-space structures and dynamical mechanisms, including the resonant coupling between eccentricity and inclination in the high-eccentricity regime. The orbit-fitting will improve knowledge of the orbital parameters of the most distant known KBOs, and will also allow for higher fidelity estimates of proximity (or lack thereof) to orbital resonances with Neptune and/or Planet 9. The observational bias analysis is important to assess the statistical significance of the apparent orbital clustering of the distant KBOs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Recently, some astronomers have proposed the existence of a distant, unseen planet, informally known as Planet 9. The evidence in support of this proposal is that the orbital characteristics of about a half-dozen of the most distant KBOs are very similar and clustered so that they appear to be influenced by the gravity of a much larger planetary body. This project examined the orbital data of the most distant KBOs and assessed the possibility that the proposed unseen planet may be shepherding these KBOs through its gravitational influence, especially through orbital resonances, in a manner somewhat similar to how Jupiter shepherds the Hilda group asteroids and the Trojan group asteroids (Jupiter's orbital period is in 3:2 ratio with the Hildas' and in 1:1 ratio with the Trojans) and how Neptune shepherds Pluto and the Plutinos (Pluto's orbital period is in 3:2 ratio with Neptune's orbital period). However, unlike these well-understood cases of orbital resonances, the orbits of the most distant KBOs are extremely eccentric and are expected to overlap with the orbit of the unseen planet. Even the gravitational effects of Neptune's own orbital resonances on these distant KBOs is not sufficiently understood. Consequently, an unseen planet's shepherding effects would have much more complex dynamics. Moreover, the uncertainties in the orbital parameters of the distant KBOs pose challenges to the mathematical assessment of the evidence for the existence of the distant planet and its properties.

In a comprehensive theoretical investigation of the phase space structure of orbital, we discovered that resonance boundaries resonances in the three-body problem are non-monotonic with eccentricity and that, contrary to previous theoretical expectation, resonance zones persist at extreme eccentricities but with shifted phases. We also discovered hitherto unknown structures that constitute "low eccentricity bridges" between neighboring resonances, structures that may facilitate adiabatic resonant migration across large radial distances in planetary systems. These discoveries about the three-body problem led us to develop a novel numerical approach for the study of orbital resonances in the realistic model including the influence of all the known planets. This new approach proved especially useful for investigating the regime of extreme orbital parameters such as those of the most distant KBOs.

We obtained new observational data which reduced the orbital uncertainties of several of the distant KBOs. With the improved orbits and our new numerical approach, we made the surprising discovery that Neptune's gravitational influence extends to these distant KBOs, despite their large distances. Neptune's surprisingly strong distant resonances can affect the observable orbital distribution of very distant KBOs. This result shows that the influence of the known planets on the apparent orbital clustering of the distant KBOs must be taken into account when we discuss the possible influence of an unseen planet.

We investigated whether the mid-plane of the observed Kuiper belt shows any unexplained effects from an unseen planet. For this calculation, we implemented a machine learning classifier to identify the set of KBOs whose forced plane can be reliably predicted from planetary theory. The results of this investigation found that the current data of KBOs is consistent with theoretical expectations, with no statistically significant indications of any warp due to an unseen planet.

We did a deep dive into the orbital dynamics of Pluto, because its orbital parameters have the smallest uncertainties of all objects in the Kuiper belt and thereby could be sensitive to the effects of an unseen planet. We discovered that the combined influence of all four known giant planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune) places Pluto in a narrow zone of orbital parameters which is bounded by very strongly chaotic orbits. This result is discouraging for the proposed existence of an unseen planet whose additional gravitational effects would likely be destabilizing on Pluto (unless the hypothetical planet were much less massive or much more distant than proposed).

This project provided scientific training to nine students (graduate and undergraduate). The results from this project were incorporated into the PI?s planetary science classes, and were included in many professional conference presentations, seminars and public talks given by the PI and co-PI. This project was featured in a 1-hr-long documentary film produced for the European public television, ARTE (https://vimeo.com/748023199/2632eeb3f3).


Last Modified: 09/14/2023
Modified by: Renu Malhotra
